results.title: Stencil colouring
results.brief_description: When Alexandre Volkoff brought the story of history’s greatest lover to the screen in Casanova (1927), he definitely needed colour. Pathé Frères developed a stencil technqiue for colouring films that brought Casanova’s costumes alive and colour to his lovers’ cheeks.

constellations_primary.name: Evolution of colour
constellations_primary.description: From stenciling film frames through to the survival of Technicolor after Hollywood stopped using it, this Constellation links early cinema to some of the world's greatest films.

results.description: When Alexandre Volkoff brought the story of history’s greatest lover to the screen in Casanova (1927), he definitely needed colour. While Technicolor was decades away, the French production company Pathé Frères had developed a technique of stencil-colouring films around 1908. This process used a template for each colour – usually between three and six – and applied it frame by frame. Pathé continued innovating, developing mechanical devices to make the process faster and easier for the more than 400 women colourists working at the company. Thanks to Pathé’s stencil method, Casanova’s costumes shimmered in pink, orange and yellow, and rosy blushes graced his lovers’ cheeks.
description_for_label: When Alexandre Volkoff brought the story of history’s greatest lover to the screen in Casanova (1927), he definitely needed colour. While Technicolor was decades away, the French production company Pathé Frères had developed a technique of stencil-colouring films around 1908. This process used a template for each colour – usually between three and six – and applied it frame by frame. Pathé continued innovating, developing mechanical devices to make the process faster and easier for the more than 400 women colourists working at the company. Thanks to Pathé’s stencil method, Casanova’s costumes shimmered in pink, orange and yellow, and rosy blushes graced his lovers’ cheeks.

results.title: Tinted film
results.brief_description: The most common methods of colouring early films were tinting and toning. Tinting was inspired by the translucent lighting gels used in theatre, while toning was adapted from photographic printing.

constellations_primary.name: Monsters, murder and mystery
constellations_primary.description: Murder and mystery hide in the shadows born from German Expressionism.

results.description: The most common methods of colouring early motion pictures were tinting and toning. Tinting was inspired by the translucent lighting gels used in theatre that washed the stage in a single glowing colour. Films were tinted by submerging frames in dye baths that saturated all the areas that weren’t black. Toning, adapted from photographic printing, coloured only the darker areas of a frame. Often, toning and tinting were both used in the one film to create moods, convey emotions and heighten tension. Other times, they were used completely randomly.
description_for_label: The most common methods of colouring early motion pictures were tinting and toning. Tinting was inspired by the translucent lighting gels used in theatre that washed the stage in a single glowing colour. Films were tinted by submerging frames in dye baths that saturated all the areas that weren’t black. Toning, adapted from photographic printing, coloured only the darker areas of a frame. Often, toning and tinting were both used in the one film to create moods, convey emotions and heighten tension. Other times, they were used completely randomly.

results.title: M.2-16mm 2T splicer
results.brief_description:
The splicer, afterwards simply know as the “Catozzo”, was born as a result of a serious form of allergy to the smell of the cement suffered by his inventor which produced the happy intuition to use adhesive tape in its place, for joining the various film ends together.
This idea was subsequently consolidated and patented all over the world, developing into all the various currently existing models. [SOURCE: https://www.cir-srl.com/ last accessed 20/06/2019]

CIR (Costruzione Incollatrici Rapide) Catozzo

Incollatrice M. 2-16mm 2T splicer
with adhesive tape
housed in original cardbox box.

Housed in storage box stamped three times with:
Michael Hudson
Phone 387 4549
Film Production & design
626 Park Street
North Carlton VIC 3054

Included are: Instructions per film 16mm
description of splicers flier that folds out.
Made in Italy. Patented

Label at the bottom of the splicer has been attached which says:
Michael Hudson
Phone 387 4549
Film Production & design
626 Park Street
North Carlton VIC 3054

Inscribed at the base: Made in Italy. US pat

silver label at the base reads:
made in Italy by
Officine Meccaniche
Dr. Leo Catozzo
00050 Santa Severa (Roma)
Tel. 0766/78008-78181

FPB A-2025

results.title: Filmo 70DR with light meter
results.brief_description:
Leather custom case housing a 16mm Bell and Howell Company film camera, and a Weston Master Universal Exposure Meter with 2 accompanying booklets housed in their original cardboard storage box.

Medium/material description (removed from field for XOS data upgrade)
001: Pentagonal shapped leather fitted case and leather strap with a maroon-coloured velvet interior in good condition.
002: Heavy metal body and two lenses.
003 Plastic and metal.
004: Cardboard lid and base.
005: Paper instruction booklet.
006: Paper instruction booklet.
007: Paper

results.title: KOK 28mm hand cranked projector
results.brief_description: In 1912, the popular Pathé Kok camera and projector arrived, which used the more standard 28mm film and cast a 30-inch picture.
results.description:
28mm hand crank projector designed by Pathe. Designed for home use, the Pathe KOK projector uses non-flammable cellulose acetate safety film and an electric light. The projector is powered by a crank handle. Contains: projector, hand crank, metal cover, 2 x metal reels.
Sticker on reel says “The property of Visual Education Centre, Education Dept. Victoria”
See video of same model (modified) of projector in use: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SG9Nvly1UB4
Was ACMI Lending Collection/ACMI Collection in 2014 audit - NR says unclear, but should keep.
28 mm gauge metal projector on wooden base.Object functions.
